title: Research
text:
Overview
My research is driven by a long-term goal of advancing personalized medicine. I focus on integrating MRI, pathology imaging, and artificial intelligence to improve cancer diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment, with the ultimate aim of making therapies more precise, efficient, and accessible for every patient.
I am particularly interested in:

Multimodal imaging integration: Combining MRI and pathology data to capture the full complexity of tumors and improve diagnostic accuracy.

Machine learning for therapy personalization: Developing predictive models that help clinicians select the optimal treatment for individual patients.

Translational impact: Creating tools that can be incorporated into clinical workflows to support real-world patient care.












Future Directions
Looking ahead, I aim to expand my work to broader applications of personalized medicine, combining imaging, genomics, and AI-driven decision support to help bring precision therapies from the lab to the clinic efficiently.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text: My central hypothesis for this study is that middle-aged adults (age 40-65) adults with heavy metal exposure (e.g. lead exposure) have higher systolic blood pressure. To test this hypothesis, I am using data gathered from NHANES during the years of 2017-March 2020 (the pre-pandemic years). In this study (Study 2 analyses), I am modeling the relationship between the concentration of lead in the blood and blood pressure.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
4.1 Data Imputation

4.1.1 Demonstration of Missing Data & Investigating Patterns of Data Missingness (MCAR, MAR, NMAR)
First, I want to find out any patterns in my missing values to understand whether the data is missing completely at random (MCAR), missing at random (MAR), or missing not at random (MNAR).









# A tibble: 9 × 3
  variable n_miss pct_miss
  <chr>     <int>    <num>
1 BPXSY1      378    15.3 
2 BPXDI1      378    15.3 
3 LBXBPB      197     7.96
4 LBXBCD      197     7.96
5 LBXBMN      197     7.96
6 SEQN          0     0   
7 RIDAGEYR      0     0   
8 RIAGENDR      0     0   
9 RIDRETH1      0     0   


The data is not missing completely at random. Missingness is observed in blocks/clusters: one cluster is for lab values (LBXBPB, LBXBCD, LBXBMN) and another is for blood pressure readings (BPXSY1, BPXDI1). Individuals who are missing one lab value are also going to be missing the others. Likewise, individuals who are missing one blood pressure reading will also be missing the others. Furthermore, it’s possible that individuals missing lab values are also more likely to have blood pressure readings missing. To investigate this, I will use a Chi square test to see if there is any dependency in the missingness of lab values and blood pressure:

# create indicators
nhanes_filtered$lab_missing  <- as.integer(
  is.na(nhanes_filtered$LBXBPB) | is.na(nhanes_filtered$LBXBCD) | is.na(nhanes_filtered$LBXBMN)
)
nhanes_filtered$bp_missing   <- as.integer(
  is.na(nhanes_filtered$BPXSY1) | is.na(nhanes_filtered$BPXDI1)
)

# Contingency table
tab <- table(nhanes_filtered$lab_missing, nhanes_filtered$bp_missing)
tab

   
       0    1
  0 2015  263
  1   82  115

# Chi-squared test
chisq.test(tab)    


    Pearson's Chi-squared test with Yates' continuity correction

data:  tab
X-squared = 303.69, df = 1, p-value < 2.2e-16

# Effect size: Cramer's V (equivalent to phi coefficient for 2x2)
library(rcompanion)
cramerV(tab)

Cramer V 
  0.3524 


The significant test result and moderate effect size suggests some dependency: individuals missing lab values are also somewhat more likely to have BP values missing (or vice versa?).
Next, I want to check if the missingness is associated with observed covariates. This makes it more likely that the missing values are MAR.



Call:
glm(formula = lab_missing ~ RIDAGEYR + RIAGENDR + RIDRETH1, family = binomial, 
    data = nhanes_filtered)

Coefficients:
                            Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)   
(Intercept)                -1.496040   0.564560  -2.650  0.00805 **
RIDAGEYR                   -0.022070   0.009855  -2.239  0.02513 * 
RIAGENDRFemale             -0.137618   0.149291  -0.922  0.35663   
RIDRETH1Other Hispanic     -0.649419   0.421871  -1.539  0.12371   
RIDRETH1Non-Hispanic White  0.234973   0.262735   0.894  0.37114   
RIDRETH1Non-Hispanic Black  0.579121   0.257134   2.252  0.02431 * 
RIDRETH1Other/Multiracial   0.428955   0.265799   1.614  0.10656   
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 1375.0  on 2474  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance: 1352.3  on 2468  degrees of freedom
AIC: 1366.3

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 6



Call:
glm(formula = bp_missing ~ RIDAGEYR + RIAGENDR + RIDRETH1, family = binomial, 
    data = nhanes_filtered)

Coefficients:
                            Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)                -1.656627   0.427797  -3.872 0.000108 ***
RIDAGEYR                   -0.004570   0.007429  -0.615 0.538452    
RIAGENDRFemale              0.141990   0.112422   1.263 0.206587    
RIDRETH1Other Hispanic      0.132636   0.231888   0.572 0.567332    
RIDRETH1Non-Hispanic White  0.029522   0.187244   0.158 0.874719    
RIDRETH1Non-Hispanic Black  0.280575   0.185378   1.514 0.130146    
RIDRETH1Other/Multiracial   0.070331   0.194831   0.361 0.718109    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 2115.7  on 2474  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance: 2110.0  on 2468  degrees of freedom
AIC: 2124

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4


From the regression otput, it appears that missingness in lab values is related to observed covariates in the dataset – certain sexes and races are more likely to have data missing. Therefore, I can plausibly assume that the data is missing at random (MAR). However, for blood pressure values, that does not seem to be the case. It is therefore possible that missingness is driven by some unobserved variable and BP values could be NMAR. However, for the purposes of this assignment, I will assume that all data is MAR. Thus, standard imputation methods like multiple imputation (MICE) are appropriate.


4.1.2 Imputation Method: MICE (Based on Desired Model that uses heavy metal concentrations in the blood + race/ethnicity + sex to predict systolic blood pressure)
I used predictive mean matching (PMM) for continuous variables. The categorical variables in the dataset (sex, race/ethnicity) had no missing values according to the heatmap in the section “Demonstration of Missing Data & Investigating Patterns of Data Missingness (MCAR, MAR, NMAR)”. Only predictor variables were imputed; the outcome variable, systolic blood pressure (BPXSY1), was not imputed.

library(mice)

# Impute filtered dataset 
# Define methods per variable
meth <- make.method(nhanes_filtered)
meth[c("LBXBPB", "LBXBCD", "LBXBMN")] <- "pmm"
meth["SEQN"] <- ""  # ID variable excluded

# Perform imputation
set.seed(123)
imp <- mice(
  nhanes_filtered,
  m = 1,       # single imputed dataset
  method = meth,
  maxit = 20,
  printFlag = FALSE    # <-- suppress iteration output
)

# Complete data after imputation
nhanes_imputed <- complete(imp, 1)



       SEQN    RIDAGEYR    RIAGENDR    RIDRETH1      LBXBPB      LBXBCD 
          0           0           0           0           0           0 
     LBXBMN      BPXSY1      BPXDI1 lab_missing  bp_missing 
          0           0           0           0           0 


The only missing values should be in the outcome variable, not the predictor variables.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
4.2 Outlier Removal
Outliers (defined as values < Q1- 1.5IQR or > Q3+1.5IQR) were removed. An alternative strategy would be to impute outliers instead of simply dropping them.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
5.2 Codebook (HTML Rendering)
Check out HTML codebook here →

library(labelled)
library(dataReporter)

# Assign variable labels
var_labels <- c(
  SEQN = "Subject ID: Individual Identifier",
  RIDAGEYR = "Age in years at screening (40-65)",
  RIAGENDR = "Sex: male or female",
  RIDRETH1 = "Race / Ethnicity",
  LBXBPB = "Blood lead (µg/dL)",
  LBXBPB_clean = "Blood lead after outlier removal",
  LBXBCD = "Blood cadmium (µg/dL)",
  LBXBCD_clean = "Blood cadmium after outlier removal",
  LBXBMN = "Blood manganese (µg/dL)",
  LBXBMN_clean = "Blood manganese after outlier removal",
  BPXSY1 = "Systolic BP, first reading",
  BPXSY1_clean = "Systolic BP, first reading after outlier removal",
  BPXDI1 = "Diastolic BP, first reading",
  BPXDI1_clean = "Diastolic BP, first reading after outlier removal"
)

# Convert your named character vector to a named list
var_labels_list <- as.list(var_labels)

# Apply labels to the dataframe
nhanes_clean <- set_variable_labels(nhanes_clean, .labels = var_labels_list)


makeCodebook(nhanes_clean, file = here::here("data/study2/codebook.html"), output = "html", replace = TRUE)

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
12.1 Quality of Fit
The full model does a much better job predicting blood pressure. It has a significantly higher adjusted \(R^2\) (full: 0.115, small: 0.009) and lower AIC (full: 13022.1, small: 13193.24) and BIC (full: 13081.06, small: 13220.04).

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
12.2 Assessing Assumptions
Moreover, in the full model, the residuals are normally-distributed with a mean of 0, exhibit no correlation, and have constant variance – meet iid assumptions. In the reduced model, the residual-vs-fitted plot shows some correlation at smaller systolic BP values, suggesting that the model is under-predicting the actual data. The small model is missing some key predictors, leading to omitted variable bias (observed as correlated residuals for small fitted values).

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
12.3 Posterior Predictive Checks
The smaller model tends to underpredict low values of BPXSY1, suggesting a possible non-linear effect or omission of an important predictor. The relationship linearizes with inclusion of demographic predictors in the full model, however, suggesting omitted variable bias.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
12.4 Comparing Models
The full model outperforms the small model in nearly every way. The performance metrics are better (including AIC and BIC, which penalize for including extra parameters; however, the additional demographic predictors were key to modeling systolic blood pressure, so including them outweighed any penalties for increasing the number of features. Also, including demographics corrected the omitted variable bias observed in the residuals-vs-fitted plot.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text: 13.2 Visualizing Predictions

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
13.3 Summarizing the Errors

# Root Mean Squared Prediction Error (RMSPE)
rmspe_small <- sqrt(mean(errors$sq_err_small))
rmspe_big   <- sqrt(mean(errors$sq_err_big))

# Mean Absolute Prediction Error (MAPE)
mape_small <- mean(errors$abs_err_small)
mape_big   <- mean(errors$abs_err_big)

# Maximum Absolute Error (MaxAE)
maxae_small <- max(errors$abs_err_small)
maxae_big   <- max(errors$abs_err_big)

# Squared correlation between actual and predicted (validated R^2)
val_r2_small <- cor(errors$actual, errors$pred_small)^2
val_r2_big   <- cor(errors$actual, errors$pred_big)^2

# Summarize in a tibble
error_summary <- tibble(
  Model = c("Small Model", "Big Model"),
  RMSPE = c(rmspe_small, rmspe_big),
  MAPE = c(mape_small, mape_big),
  MaxAE = c(maxae_small, maxae_big),
  R2_val = c(val_r2_small, val_r2_big)
) %>%
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), round, 3))

# Display nicely
library(DT)
datatable(error_summary, options = list(dom = 't', paging = FALSE), rownames = FALSE)

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
13.4 Comparing the Models
The big model has slightly lower RMSPE and MAPE, and its predicted range closely matches the observed systolic BP, while the small model predicts both high and low values poorly. Its predictions are all very similar – from the scatter plot, the model seems to be guessing the average systolic blood pressure value in the training set. This is likely because the predictors that meaningfully describe systolic blood pressure are absent from the model, and the model is just guessing. Based on these metrics and the scatter plots, I would prefer the big model for prediction in this test sample.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
14.1 Chosen Model
I chose the big model.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
14.2 Answering My Question
I see no evidence that blood concentrations of heavy metals have a relationship with systolic blood pressure. This goes against my hypothesis. However, my hypothesis was based on papers looking at individuals with extremely high lead levels in the blood (>5 µg/dL), but patients in my data seldom had blood levels this high. Moreover, surprisingly (according to Study 2 and my dashboard), blood lead levels do not appear to be correlated with sociodemographic variables (and are not subsumed by any sociodemographic variables). During preprocessing, I removed outliers (really high blood levels of lead, cadium, and manganese), and perhaps if I had left those values in the dataset, my result may have been different. However, there were so few individuals with high levels of heavy metals in the blood that the effect would likely have been negligible.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
text:
14.3 Next Steps
Since demographics have a strong relationship with systolic blood pressure, I would like to investigate additional demographic variables, such as education, and how they are related to systolic blood pressure. I would also like to replicate my analyses on diastolic blood pressure to see if the same trend holds.

title: Blood Pressure Determinants: Investigating Relationship Between Lead Exposure and High Blood Pressure
NHANES Data Exploration: Heavy Metal Exposure & High blood Pressure
text: My central hypothesis for this study is that middle-aged adults (age 40-65) adults with heavy metal exposure (e.g. lead exposure) have higher systolic blood pressure. To test this hypothesis, I am using data gathered from NHANES during the years of 2017-March 2020 (the pre-pandemic years). In this study (Study 1 analyses), I am performing data exploration to understand the distributions for each variable and investigate relationships between variables.

title: NHANES Data Exploration: Heavy Metal Exposure & High blood Pressure
NHANES Data Exploration: Heavy Metal Exposure & High blood Pressure
section: 7.1 Analysis B: Comparing 2 Means with Independent Samples (Blood Lead Levels by Sex)
text:
7.1 Analysis B: Comparing 2 Means with Independent Samples (Blood Lead Levels by Sex)
Question: Is the blood lead level different in males and females?
Dataset Description: The dataset was stratified by sex. Mean blood lead levels (LBXBPB_clean_log), were compared between the two sexes (male, female). There were 769 males and 821 females in the dataset.
Main analysis: A two-tailed t-test was used to compare the difference in mean blood lead levels (log-transformed) between males and females. A significance level of 0.1 was used. The effect size (Cohen’s d) was also computed (small: 0.2, medium: 0.5, large: 0.8). This set-up is essentially equivalent to univariate OLS, where the beta coefficient (\(\beta_1\)) corresponds to the difference in means of the two groups and the intercept (\(\beta_0\)) corresponds to the mean lead concentration of the reference group. OLS assumes that the data (or rather, the errors) follow a normal distribution, the errors are independent, and the errors have a constant variance. \[log(lead\_conc) = \beta_0 + \beta_1(male\_sex)\] \[lead\_conc = e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1(male\_sex)}\] \[\text{Fold change }lead\_conc = e^{\beta_1}\]
Conclusions: The median blood lead level was 0.71 ± 0.25 (mean ± SD) for males and 0.65 ± 0.25 for females, which translates to a 6% (difference in means: 0.71-0.65 = 0.06 \(\rightarrow\) fold change: \(e^{0.06} = 1.06\), \(\rightarrow\) 6% increase) difference in blood lead concentrations between males and females. The difference was statistically significant at the 0.1 level, but the effect size was low (0.26). I conclude that males and females have no appreciable difference in blood lead levels.

  n_Male n_Female mean_Male mean_Female sd_Male sd_Female t_statistic   p_value
   <int>    <int>     <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>
1    769      821     0.711       0.646   0.248     0.251        5.15 0.0000003
# ℹ 1 more variable: cohen_d <dbl>

title: NHANES Data Exploration: Heavy Metal Exposure & High blood Pressure
section: 7.2 Analysis C: Comparing Blood Lead Levels Across Races
text:
7.2 Analysis C: Comparing Blood Lead Levels Across Races
Question: Are blood lead levels different between races?
Dataset Description: The dataset was stratified by race (Mexican American, other Hispanic, non-Hispanic white, non-Hispanic black, other/multiracial). Mean blood levels of lead (LBXBPB_clean_log), were compared across the 5 racial/ethnic groups. There were 459 individuals identifying as non-Hispanic white, 249 individuals identifying as Mexican American, 179 as other Hispanic, 376 as non-Hispanic black, and 327 as other/multiracial.
Main analysis: Race/ethnicity was dummy-coded. A multivariate OLS model was used to compare mean blood lead levels, setting non-Hispanic white as the reference group. A significance level of 0.1 was used. This set-up is similar to an ANOVA followed by post-hoc testing. OLS assumes that the errors are iid, follow a normal distribution with a mean of 0, and have constant variance.
Conclusions: The mean blood lead level was 0.64 ± 0.25 (mean ± SD) for non-Hispanic whites, 0.66 ± 0.24 for Mexican Americans, 0.59 ± 0.24 for other Hispanics, 0.71 ± 0.26 for blacks, and 0.74 ± 0.24 for multiracial individuals. This translates into a 1.7% increase in blood lead levels in Mexican Americans compared to non-Hispanic whites, a 5.2% decrease in other Hispanics, a 6.23% increase in black individuals, and a 10.0% increase in blood lead levels multiracial individuals. All the comparisons were statistically significant except for Mexican Americans, whose blood lead levels were closer to the reference group. In conclusion,

title: Bridging Curiosity and Care: The Beginning of My MD-PhD Journey
text: Clinical-Translational Research

title: Bridging Curiosity and Care: The Beginning of My MD-PhD Journey
text:
A Patient’s Hope

“Thanks, Sofie,” said Mrs. H, squeezing my hand. She was suffering from a chronic leg wound, for which few treatments were available. I knew I could do more. Mrs. H’s hope for a cure inspired me to pursue clinical-translational research, and it became a defining moment in my journey toward becoming a physician-scientist.

title: Bridging Curiosity and Care: The Beginning of My MD-PhD Journey
text:
From Compassion to Research



During my undergraduate studies, I wanted to learn how I could one day address unmet clinical needs like Mrs. H’s. I joined Dr. Edward Botchwey’s lab to explore stem cell therapies for regenerative medicine. I applied statistical and machine learning approaches to identify biomarkers in stem cells that correlated with therapeutic outcomes. It was here that I realized the need for personalizing teatment approaches.
To explore my intetest in computational research and personalized medicine, I joined Dr. May Wang’s lab. There, I developed a personalized model for predicting heart disease risk. This experience reinforced how computational tools can enable precision medicine by helping clinicians make patient-specific decisions. It was here that I realized the unique power of the MD-PhD path: combining deep clinical insight with technical expertise to develop therapies tailored toward each patient.

title: Bridging Curiosity and Care: The Beginning of My MD-PhD Journey
text:
Entering the MD-PhD Phase

AI for Cancer Management



As an MD-PhD student at Case Western Reserve University, I now integrate MRI, pathology imaging, and AI in the INVent Lab to personalize cancer care. Working alongside radiologists, pathologists, and oncologists, I help develop predictive models to identify patients who may benefit from less invasive treatments, learning that effective therapy always depends on individual patient characteristics.

title: Bridging Curiosity and Care: The Beginning of My MD-PhD Journey
text:
Looking Ahead
I aspire to bridge AI research and clinical practice, developing tools that improve patient outcomes and make personalized medicine the standard of care. Beyond research, I am passionate about mentoring, science communication, and community outreach, sharing biomedical innovation with students and the public alike.


This blog will share reflections on my research journey, insights into AI in healthcare, and the personal experiences that continue to shape my path as a physician-scientist.

title: About
text:
I am an MD-PhD student in Biomedical Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, where I am pursuing my long-term goal of advancing personalized medicine. I am deeply motivated by the belief that medical care should be tailored to each individual—making treatments not only more effective, but also more streamlined, affordable, and accessible to all patients.
My current research focuses on integrating MRI, pathology imaging, and artificial intelligence to personalize cancer management. By combining insights across different imaging modalities with advanced computational methods, I aim to develop tools that help clinicians deliver the right treatment to the right patient at the right time.
Beyond research, I am passionate about science communication, mentoring, and community outreach. I enjoy helping others discover science, supporting students as they find their paths in STEM, and engaging with the public to make complex scientific ideas approachable and meaningful.
Looking ahead, I aspire to build a career at the intersection of medicine, engineering, and innovation, working toward a future where personalized medicine is the standard of care.

title: About
text:
Curriculum Vitae
📄 Download my CV (PDF)

title: About
text:
Life Outside the Lab
In my free time, I enjoy spending time outdoors… in any kind of weather. I love hiking, kayaking, apple picking, and anything else that involves being outside. I also enjoy visiting art and history museums and playing board games with friends. And of course, nothing beats a cozy night in with a cup of tea and a good TV show.

title: Project A Task B Write-Up
text:
Central Hypothesis
My central hypothesis for this study is that middle-aged adults (age 40-65) adults with heavy metal exposure (particularly lead exposure) have higher systolic blood pressure. This question is motivated by several studies showing a link between high blood lead levels and elevated prevalence of cardiovascular disease, potentially as a result of inflammation. To test this hypothesis, I used data gathered from NHANES during the years of 2017-March 2020 (the pre-pandemic years). First, I conducted data visualization and exploration (Study 1) to understand the data distributions, variable relationships, and trends. Next, I modeled the relationship between systolic blood pressure and the concentrations of 3 heavy metals (lead, cadmium, and manganese) while also controlling for demographic covariates.

title: Project A Task B Write-Up
text:
Dataset Description
The NHANES dataset from 2017-2020 consists of 9254 observations collected from individuals age 0-80. After filtering for individuals ages 40-65, 2475 observations were left. Missing data were imputed assuming missing at random (Study 2) or dropped (Study 1). For Study 1, concentrations of heavy metals in the blood were log-normalized.

title: Project A Task B Write-Up
text:
High Blood Pressure Prevalence
First, I calculated the prevalence of high blood pressure. Systolic blood pressure was binarized (HighBP: 1 = systolic BP > 140 mmHg, 0 = systolic BP \(\leq\) 140 mmHg, where 1 represents high blood pressure and 0 represents low-normal blood pressure). Prevalence was computed as the fraction of cases with high blood pressure (HighBP = 1).

title: Project A Task B Write-Up
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis
Next, I conducted some preliminary data visualization and statistical testing to explore data distributions, variable relationships, and understand overall trends. I examined the prevalence of high blood pressure (outcome vaiable) by age, sex, and race/ethnicity. I created linear models (ANOVA equivalent) to compare mean systolic blood pressure between different racial/ethnic groups and conducted a univariate t-test (equivalent of univariate OLS) to compare mean blood pressure by sex. I computed Cohen’s d to assess effect size. I also compared the prevalence of high blood pressure (systolic BP > 140 mmHg) by sex and racial/ethnic groups using Chi squared testing and relied on Cramer’s V for effect size.
Likewise, I examined blood concentrations of the 3 heavy metals by demographic group. I plotted the distributions of blood lead, cadmium, and manganese concentrations in my dashboard. For lead, I also examined the distribution of blood lead levels by sex, age, and racial/ethnic group.
Finally, I created a linear model (OLS) that integrates all the variables to answer my question and understand to what extent blood lead levels are associated with systolic blood pressure, after controlling for demographic covariates, which influence systolic blood pressure as well.

title: sofiyavyshnya
text:
Sofiya Vyshnya
I am an MD-PhD student in Biomedical Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, dedicated to advancing personalized medicine. My research integrates MRI, pathology imaging, and artificial intelligence to improve cancer care and make therapies more streamlined, affordable, and accessible. Beyond the lab, I am passionate about science communication, mentoring, and community outreach.

Download my CV
